title: Decoding the Defiance of Henry VIII’s First Wife
abstract: Using a process she called “early modern Wordle,” a scholar claims to have uncovered a hidden message from Catherine of Aragon in a book of jewelry designs.

multimedia.caption: Vanessa Braganza, a history Ph.D. student, at King’s College Chapel in Cambridge, England. Many parts of the chapel are adorned with ciphers, or coded symbols.
multimedia.copyright: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Vanessa Braganza, a history Ph.D. student, at King’s College Chapel in Cambridge, England. Many parts of the chapel are adorned with ciphers, or coded symbols.
multimedia.copyright: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Vanessa Braganza, a history Ph.D. student, at King’s College Chapel in Cambridge, England. Many parts of the chapel are adorned with ciphers, or coded symbols.
multimedia.copyright: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times

title: Beach Bunny Is Building an Indie-Rock Career in a Time of TikTok
abstract: The singer-songwriter Lili Trifilio has had two songs connect — and get slightly misconstrued — on the app. With more ears on her band’s second album, what message will she deliver?

multimedia.caption: “It still sounds like Beach Bunny,” Lily Trifilio said of her band’s new album, “but it just sounds a little more grown up. Which I’m happy with, because I’m growing up.”
multimedia.copyright: Lyndon French for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: “It still sounds like Beach Bunny,” Lily Trifilio said of her band’s new album, “but it just sounds a little more grown up. Which I’m happy with, because I’m growing up.”

title: A Walk in Their Heels: Meet the Hustle Evangelist
abstract: Abdiel Jacobsen, a former Martha Graham dancer, found freedom in hustle, which offers a progressive, gender-neutral vision of partnered social dance.

multimedia.caption: Abdiel Jacobsen, known professionally as Abdiel, in Central Park. Hustle is “about everyone coming together, just as they are, under the sermon of the music,” Abdiel said.
multimedia.copyright: Lia Clay Miller for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Abdiel Jacobsen, known professionally as Abdiel, in Central Park. Hustle is “about everyone coming together, just as they are, under the sermon of the music,” Abdiel said.

title: Girls Are Outnumbered in Jazz. At This Summer Camp, They Run the Show.
abstract: Jazz Camp for Girls, a four-day program in Denmark, has expanded to Finland, Poland and Sweden this year, giving young musicians a space to play music and build friendships.

multimedia.caption: Alma Elsa Olivia Sulkunen, a 9-year-old saxophonist, attended Jazz Camp for Girls in Copenhagen this year. “I really hope that for her, it can just be about the joy of making music,” her mother said.
multimedia.copyright: Betina Garcia for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Alma Elsa Olivia Sulkunen, a 9-year-old saxophonist, attended Jazz Camp for Girls in Copenhagen this year. “I really hope that for her, it can just be about the joy of making music,” her mother said.

title: Burna Boy Faces Success and Second Thoughts on ‘Love, Damini’
abstract: On his sixth album, the Nigerian superstar admits some regrets.

multimedia.caption: The core of Burna Boy’s music is the elegantly minimal percussion — hand-played and electronic — of Nigerian Afrobeats.
multimedia.copyright: Daniel Obasi for The New York Times

title: ‘Both Sides of the Blade’ Review: Who Do You Love?
abstract: In the latest film from Claire Denis, Juliette Binoche plays a Parisian radio journalist in a romantic quandary.

multimedia.caption: Vincent Lindon and Juliette Binoche in “Both Sides of the Blade,” directed by Claire Denis.
Vincent Lindon and Juliette Binoche in “Both Sides of the Blade,” directed by Claire Denis.
Vincent Lindon and Juliette Binoche in “Both Sides of the Blade,” directed by Claire Denis.

title: What if Juliet Lived? A Pop Hitmaker’s ‘& Juliet’ Heads to Broadway.
abstract: The jukebox musical, which is already running in London, features songs by the Swedish writer and producer Max Martin, including “Since U Been Gone” and “ … Baby One More Time.”

multimedia.caption: The company of “& Juliet.” The show will transfer to New York from Toronto in the fall.
The company of “& Juliet.” The show will transfer to New York from Toronto in the fall.
The company of “& Juliet.” The show will transfer to New York from Toronto in the fall.

title: Man Who Shot the Rapper Nipsey Hussle Is Convicted of Murder
abstract: A jury found Eric R. Holder Jr. guilty of first-degree murder for the 2019 killing of Hussle, an artist who devoted his adult life to championing his South Los Angeles neighborhood.
byline: By Jill Cowan and Joe Coscarelli

multimedia.caption: Eric R. Holder Jr., who has been found guilty of first-degree murder in the death of Nipsey Hussle in 2019, listened as his murder trial got underway.
multimedia.copyright: Pool photo by Frederick M. Brown

title: Jerry Harris Sentenced to 12 Years for Sex Crimes Involving Minors
abstract: Mr. Harris, who shot to reality-TV fame in the Netflix documentary series “Cheer,” had pleaded guilty to federal charges related to soliciting child sexual abuse imagery and illegal sexual conduct with a minor.

multimedia.caption: The sentencing of Jerry Harris concludes a case that began in September 2020.
The sentencing of Jerry Harris concludes a case that began in September 2020.
The sentencing of Jerry Harris concludes a case that began in September 2020.

title: ‘The Collaboration,’ About Warhol and Basquiat, Plans Broadway Bow
abstract: The play, by Anthony McCarten, will be presented this fall by the Manhattan Theater Club, following a run earlier this year at the Young Vic in London.

multimedia.caption: Jeremy Pope and Paul Bettany in “The Collaboration” at the Young Vic.
Jeremy Pope and Paul Bettany in “The Collaboration” at the Young Vic.
Jeremy Pope and Paul Bettany in “The Collaboration” at the Young Vic.

title: Ni Kuang, Prolific Hong Kong Novelist and Screenwriter, Dies at 87
abstract: Best known for fantastical thrillers that doubled as political allegories, he also wrote hundreds of martial arts films for Bruce Lee and others.

multimedia.caption: Ni Kuang in 2006 in Hong Kong. He was perhaps best known for the “Wisely” series, a collection of adventure stories about encounters with aliens and battles with intelligent monsters that sometimes contained pointed political criticism.
multimedia.copyright: Martin Chan/South China Morning Post via Getty Images

multimedia.caption: Ni Kuang in 2006 in Hong Kong. He was perhaps best known for the “Wisely” series, a collection of adventure stories about encounters with aliens and battles with intelligent monsters that sometimes contained pointed political criticism.
multimedia.copyright: Martin Chan/South China Morning Post via Getty Images

multimedia.caption: Ni Kuang in 2006 in Hong Kong. He was perhaps best known for the “Wisely” series, a collection of adventure stories about encounters with aliens and battles with intelligent monsters that sometimes contained pointed political criticism.

title: ‘Moon, 66 Questions’ Review: Daddy Issues
abstract: This elliptical drama by the Greek writer-director Jacqueline Lentzou rousingly summons the inner turmoil of a young woman who returns home to care for her ailing father.

multimedia.caption: Sofia Kokkali in “Moon, 66 Questions,” directed by Jacqueline Lentzou.
Sofia Kokkali in “Moon, 66 Questions,” directed by Jacqueline Lentzou.
Sofia Kokkali in “Moon, 66 Questions,” directed by Jacqueline Lentzou.

title: The Enduring Appeal of the Self-Taught Artist
abstract: For centuries, those who eschewed formal training have been either marginalized or obsessed over. Why are we so enthralled by people who create on their own terms?

multimedia.caption: Tamo Jugeli in her Tbilisi, Georgia, studio.
multimedia.copyright: Courtesy of the artist and Polina Berlin Gallery

multimedia.caption: Tamo Jugeli in her Tbilisi, Georgia, studio.

title: Why Are We Still Talking About Black Mountain College?
abstract: In 1933, a handful of renegade teachers opened a school in rural North Carolina that would go on to shape American art and art education for decades to come.

multimedia.caption: An image by Josef Albers of John R. P. French Jr.’s psychology class on the deck of Black Mountain College’s Studies Building, circa 1941-42.
multimedia.copyright: © 2022 The Josef and Anni Albers Foundation/Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York

title: ‘This Much I Know to Be True’ Review: Nick Cave Prepares for the Stage
abstract: A new music documentary by Andrew Dominik explores the collaboration of Cave and Warren Ellis.
des_facet: This Much I Know to Be True (Movie)

title: ‘Cop Secret’ Review: Bang Bang, Kiss Kiss
abstract: In this Icelandic spoof of Hollywood action movies, two rival police officers make a love connection.

multimedia.caption: In “Cop Secret,” Bussi (Audunn Blondal), Iceland’s toughest police officer, is forcibly partnered with his suave rival from a neighboring precinct.
In “Cop Secret,” Bussi (Audunn Blondal), Iceland’s toughest police officer, is forcibly partnered with his suave rival from a neighboring precinct.

title: ‘Dreaming Walls: Inside the Chelsea Hotel’ Review: Bohemia’s Holdouts
abstract: This documentary offers an immersion in the lives of residents who keep the building’s spirit as a home for artists alive through a protracted renovation.
des_facet: Dreaming Walls: Inside the Chelsea Hotel (Movie)

multimedia.caption: The artist Bettina Grossman in a scene from the documentary “Dreaming Walls: Inside the Chelsea Hotel.”

title: Blockbusters at Balenciaga and Margiela
abstract: Plus performance art at Viktor & Rolf. Sometimes a fashion show is not just a fashion show.

multimedia.caption: Dua Lipa, Nicole Kidman and Kim Kardashian in Balenciaga, couture, fall 2022.
Dua Lipa, Nicole Kidman and Kim Kardashian in Balenciaga, couture, fall 2022.

title: On the London Stage, Families in Disarray
abstract: Two new plays, “The Southbury Child” and “Mad House,” explore domestic discord with contrasting degrees of success.

multimedia.caption: Sarah Twomey and Alex Jennings in Stephen Beresford’s “The Southbury Child,” directed by Nicholas Hytner at the Bridge Theater.
Sarah Twomey and Alex Jennings in Stephen Beresford’s “The Southbury Child,” directed by Nicholas Hytner at the Bridge Theater.

title: Bradford Freeman, Last of the ‘Band of Brothers,’ Dies at 97
abstract: The exploits of his World War II paratroop company were chronicled in a best-selling book and then in an acclaimed HBO mini-series.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

multimedia.caption: Bradford Freeman, the last survivor of the famed World War II Army unit featured in the book and mini-series “Band of Brothers,” in 2016.
Bradford Freeman, the last survivor of the famed World War II Army unit featured in the book and mini-series “Band of Brothers,” in 2016.
Bradford Freeman, the last survivor of the famed World War II Army unit featured in the book and mini-series “Band of Brothers,” in 2016.

title: A Feminist, Neorealist, Communist Film, and a Plain Great Movie
abstract: “One Way or Another,” from 1974, is a class-conscious love story involving a macho worker and a well-to-do schoolteacher in Cuba.

multimedia.caption: Mario Balmaseda, left, and Yolanda Cuéllar in “One Way or Another,” by the Afro-Cuban director Sara Gómez.
Mario Balmaseda, left, and Yolanda Cuéllar in “One Way or Another,” by the Afro-Cuban director Sara Gómez.
Mario Balmaseda, left, and Yolanda Cuéllar in “One Way or Another,” by the Afro-Cuban director Sara Gómez.

title: ‘Hello, Goodbye and Everything in Between’ Review: Break Cute?
abstract: In this adaptation of Jennifer E. Smith’s young adult novel, two high school seniors agree to split up in a year. Will they honor their pact?
des_facet: Hello, Goodbye, and Everything in Between (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Jordan Fisher as Aidan and Talia Ryder as Clare in “Hello, Goodbye and Everything in Between.”
Jordan Fisher as Aidan and Talia Ryder as Clare in “Hello, Goodbye and Everything in Between.”
Jordan Fisher as Aidan and Talia Ryder as Clare in “Hello, Goodbye and Everything in Between.”

title: Lesley Gore’s Archive, Open to All, Arrives at the New York Public Library
abstract: The collection, which includes family photos, scrapbook pages and annotated music, traces the singer’s arc from releasing bubble gum hits to creating a powerful feminist statement.

multimedia.caption: Lesley Gore in 1965. The singer died in 2015, and her archives are now available at the New York Public Library.
Lesley Gore in 1965. The singer died in 2015, and her archives are now available at the New York Public Library.
Lesley Gore in 1965. The singer died in 2015, and her archives are now available at the New York Public Library.

title: The Academy Museum Names Jacqueline Stewart as New Leader
abstract: The film historian and preservationist specializes in Black cinema and silent movies. She had been serving as the institution’s chief artistic and programming officer.

multimedia.caption: Jacqueline Stewart at the TCM Classic Film Festival in Los Angeles in April.
Jacqueline Stewart at the TCM Classic Film Festival in Los Angeles in April.
Jacqueline Stewart at the TCM Classic Film Festival in Los Angeles in April.

title: ‘Son of Elsewhere,’ a Funny and Frank Story About Life After a Big Move
abstract: In his “memoir in pieces,” Elamin Abdelmahmoud writes about the years after he and his family emigrated from Sudan to Canada when he was 12.
des_facet: Son of Elsewhere: A Memoir in Pieces (Book)

title: The Real Reason the Minions Have Taken Over the World
abstract: Wordless, antic, physical: The film franchise’s comedy is nothing like prevailing family entertainment, and that’s a good thing.

multimedia.caption: From “Minions: The Rise of Gru,” Otto, left, Stuart and Bob, all voiced by Pierre Coffin.
From “Minions: The Rise of Gru,” Otto, left, Stuart and Bob, all voiced by Pierre Coffin.

title: In Newport, Artists Turn Tables on the Gilded Age
abstract: In historic mansions where Sargent and Boldini reigned, a new generation of portraitists unites against the Old Guard for a summer show.
des_facet: Pictus Porrectus: Reconsidering the Full-Length Portrait (Exhibit)

multimedia.caption: At the Isaac Bell House in Newport, R.I., the curators of “Pictus Porrectus” invited artists to reimagine the Gilded Age portrait for today. Left, Henry Taylor’s “Portrait of Chase Hall,” 2014; right, the artist Chase Hall’s self-referential portrait, “The Autodidact,” 2022.
multimedia.copyright: Tony Luong for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: At the Isaac Bell House in Newport, R.I., the curators of “Pictus Porrectus” invited artists to reimagine the Gilded Age portrait for today. Left, Henry Taylor’s “Portrait of Chase Hall,” 2014; right, the artist Chase Hall’s self-referential portrait, “The Autodidact,” 2022.
multimedia.copyright: Tony Luong for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: At the Isaac Bell House in Newport, R.I., the curators of “Pictus Porrectus” invited artists to reimagine the Gilded Age portrait for today. Left, Henry Taylor’s “Portrait of Chase Hall,” 2014; right, the artist Chase Hall’s self-referential portrait, “The Autodidact,” 2022.
multimedia.copyright: Tony Luong for The New York Times

title: Tobias Kratzer Is Leading Opera’s Next Generation of Directors
abstract: With concurrent productions in France that are fresh yet faithful, Kratzer is “renewing opera, but renewing it intelligently,” says one colleague.

abstract: David Salle, Miranda July, Mariko Mori and others talk about their experiences attending (or leaving or forgoing) the academy.

title: The Shape-Shifting Sherlock Holmes, Now Playing the Villain
abstract: The world’s first consulting detective has appeared in many disguises, including clergyman, sailor and old woman. Now, in a new podcast, he is cast as a monster.

title: Her ‘Chagall’ Is Headed for the Trash. How’s That for Caveat Emptor?
abstract: Stephanie Clegg paid $90,000 for a Marc Chagall painting at a Sotheby’s auction in 1994. It was reappraised for $100,000 in 2008. Now an expert panel in France wants to destroy it as a fake.

multimedia.caption: Stephanie Clegg, an art collector, said she is upset that a Marc Chagall painting she bought at Sotheby’s in 1994 has been declared a fake and is threatened with being destroyed.
multimedia.copyright: Aaron Richter for The New York Times

title: U.K. Museums Face a Sticky Problem From Climate Protests
abstract: Activists are gluing themselves to the frames of iconic paintings. They say it does not matter whether their actions are popular — only whether they are noticed.

multimedia.caption: Protesters glued to John Constable’s “The Hay Wain” on Monday. The National Gallery in London said the action caused “some disruption to the surface of the varnish on the painting” and “minor damage to its frame.”
multimedia.copyright: Kirsty O'Connor/Press Association, via Associated Press

multimedia.caption: Protesters glued to John Constable’s “The Hay Wain” on Monday. The National Gallery in London said the action caused “some disruption to the surface of the varnish on the painting” and “minor damage to its frame.”
multimedia.copyright: Kirsty O'Connor/Press Association, via Associated Press
